messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] gold dragonfish tsuba

messages.messageBody:
> -T
>
> I am the Gorby dude............ although Milt is still the boss.
> Tremendous tsuba, no doubt about it. I thought it might be a carp
> turning ito a dragon after jumping through the 'dragon gate'. A theme
> often seen on Chinese and Japanese porcleain. Could that be another

>

>

Matt-
That was my initial thought, but checking my references it was clear
this was a Shachi and not a carp crossing the Toryu-mon.

-t

BTW at one time there was a guy in the US Navy named Larry. Don't know
his last name it is lost to time. He was such a screw up everything he
touched went to Shizuoka if you get my drift. His name became
synonymous with F-ups. When I worked at Hunters Point Naval Shipyard,
"He pulled a Larry" or "Watch out you don't Larry that up" were common
expressions. You may be THE Gorby, but it doesn't mean that every now
and again Milt or anyone one of us might be a Gorby, Gorby!

messages.subject: Re: gold dragonfish tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: ... construction of a copper core sandwiched between thin gold layers and finished with a fukurin is not that unusual.  It s seen in Momoyama period Ko-Kinko
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> Milt,
> Tom is of course right about the motif being a shachihoko. The
construction of a copper core sandwiched between thin gold layers and
finished with a fukurin is not that unusual. It's seen in Momoyama
period Ko-Kinko work for example, often with wave and floating mon
motifs. Most of these are not as high relief as yours and are
usually not so crisply carved. The shape of the hitsu-ana and the
general workmanship of this one seem more in line with the Edo
period. Of course the hitsu-ana could have been enlarged later and
relined with gold.
>
> The Genroku period was the next point in time when this kind of
display was in style. My guess is that your guard is from that time
It doesn't look very late to me. It could possibly be earlier than
Genroku. Hard to say more without seeing it.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> http://tinyurl.com/3cmud
>

thank you, Jim, -t und Cary for the insight.
Glad it is not a Yokohama special.......
I will submit this for the NTHK Chicago 04 shinsa.

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] gold dragonfish tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Milt, Tom is of course right about the motif being a shachihoko.  The construction of a copper core sandwiched between thin gold layers and finished with a
messages.messageBody:
Milt,
Tom is of course right about the motif being a shachihoko. The construction of a copper core sandwiched between thin gold layers and finished with a fukurin is not that unusual. It's seen in Momoyama period Ko-Kinko work for example, often with wave and floating mon motifs. Most of these are not as high relief as yours and are usually not so crisply carved. The shape of the hitsu-ana and the general workmanship of this one seem more in line with the Edo period. Of course the hitsu-ana could have been enlarged later and relined with gold.

The Genroku period was the next point in time when this kind of display was in style. My guess is that your guard is from that time It doesn't look very late to me. It could possibly be earlier than Genroku. Hard to say more without seeing it.

Jim



http://tinyurl.com/3cmud

Gorby und I have been digging through all the tsuba books we
have......... nothing like this turns up in any book.


So..... this could be a tourist Yokohama special not worthy of
illustration ? something so rare that few collections has an example ?

By the way, it's not gold paint.........it's very thin gold foil
cover.

Cary ? Jim ? Herr professor Robson ? any thoughts ??
anyone ? please??

milt

messages.messageBody:
-T

I am the Gorby dude............ although Milt is still the boss.
Tremendous tsuba, no doubt about it. I thought it might be a carp
turning ito a dragon after jumping through the 'dragon gate'. A theme
often seen on Chinese and Japanese porcleain. Could that be another
explanation or am I just full of it ?

hahaha

- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: sanbruno@... [mailto:junkmail@...]
Verzonden: vrijdag 2 januari 2004 4:48
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: RE: [nihontostudy] gold dragonfish tsuba


Milt!
You're the gorby dude! This is a Shachi, an imaginary sea creature that
was
small but fierce, in the Momoyama period images of it were placed on the
rooftops of castles to ward off fire. The Golden Shachi of Nagoya being
of
greatest fame, they were oft copied (and stolen).A very cool tsuba IMHO,
-t

P.S. though reputed to eat whales and cut ships in half with their fins
these are NOT killer whales, though oddly, Shachi is translated as
"Orca"...

messages.messageBody:
Milt!
You're the gorby dude! This is a Shachi, an imaginary sea creature that was
small but fierce, in the Momoyama period images of it were placed on the
rooftops of castles to ward off fire. The Golden Shachi of Nagoya being of
greatest fame, they were oft copied (and stolen).A very cool tsuba IMHO,
-t

P.S. though reputed to eat whales and cut ships in half with their fins
these are NOT killer whales, though oddly, Shachi is translated as "Orca"...
